record.isolationComments: Isolated by Martinus W. Beijerinck in 1920s and stored at the Netherland Culture Collection of Bacteria (NCCB). Isolated from surface coastal seawater.
record.comments: Genome sequence of Vibrio jasicida MWB 21. The strain was was part of a collection of bacteria isolated by Martinus W. Beijerinck in 1920s and stored at the Netherland Culture Collection of Bacteria (NCCB). The sequencing was done as a part of a study analyzing closely related bacteria in the so-called Harveyi clade (genus Vibrio, family Vibrionaceae).

The CyanoGEBA Sequencing Project is part of the DOE Joint Genome Institute’s Genomic Encyclopedia of Bacteria and Archaea initiative. The CyanoGEBA project is a collaboration between the JGI and the Pasteur Culture Collection aimed at improving sequencing coverage of the cyanobacterial phylum based on phylogenetic criteria.

taxonLineageNames.item: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Norwich

record.comments: Genome sequencing project
The core group or Harveyi clade of Vibrio is composed of several closely related species. The type strain of V. campbellii CAIM 519T will be used for phylogenomic studies.

The recently elucidated complete genome sequence of Vibrio harveyi CAIM 1792 provides an opportunity to understand the genetic determinants responsible for the unique morbidity and mortality this organism causes when pathogenizing the white shrimp, Litopenaeus vannamei. In this study, we compared the genome of V. harveyi CAIM 1792 with draft genome sequences from other V. harveyi strains and closely related species (V. owensii, V. rotiferianus, V. campbellii) to determine the level of genetic conservation among these strains/species and to identify genetic determinants involved in pathogenicity which are unique to V. harveyi CAIM 1792.
Acinetobacter Sequencing

record.isolationComments: Isolated from diseased Channel catfish in 1976, in Georgia, USA and obtained from ATCC bioresource center
record.comments: Edwardsiella ictaluri was isolated from diseased Channel catfish in 1976, in Georgia, USA and obtained from ATCC bioresource center.Edwardsiella ictaluri is specifically adapted to the channel catfish host and the causative agent of enteric septicemia of catfish (ESC) around the world. ATCC 33202 was first isolated in 1976 and the type strain of Edwardsiella ictaluri. Previous genome sequence and proteome analysis of E. ictaluri 93-146 have provided an overview of this species. Comparative analysis of different E. ictaluri strains may comprehensively and systematically improve our understanding of the genetic diversity and microevolution of this species.
record.sequencingCenters: East China University of Science and Technology

record.comments: This study reports the release of the complete nucleotide sequence of Anabaena sp. ATCC 33047 (Anabaena CA). This organism is a filamentous, nitrogen-fixing marine cyanobacterium which under salt stress conditions accumulates sucrose internally (Reed et al. 1984). It was collected in the estuarial environment of Port Aransas, Texas and exhibits a high growth rate, wide range of optimal temperature and pH, and tolerance to high irradiance (Stacy et al. 1977; Reed et al. 1984; Moreno et al. 2003). The elucidation of the genome will contribute to the understanding of cyanobacterial diversity.

The recently elucidated complete genome sequence of Vibrio harveyi CAIM 1792 provides an opportunity to understand the genetic determinants responsible for the unique morbidity and mortality this organism causes when pathogenizing the white shrimp, Litopenaeus vannamei. In this study, we compared the genome of V. harveyi CAIM 1792 with draft genome sequences from other V. harveyi strains and closely related species (V. owensii, V. rotiferianus, V. campbellii) to determine the level of genetic conservation among these strains/species and to identify genetic determinants involved in pathogenicity which are unique to V. harveyi CAIM 1792.

record.comments: FDA, in collaboration with the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), the Department of Defense (DoD) and the Institute for Genome Sciences at the University of Maryland, established a publicly available, well-curated reference database (FDA-ARGOS: dAtabase for Regulatory Grade micrObial Sequences; BioProject 231221) of regulatory-grade-quality sequences from diverse infectious microorganisms. This database, which is still growing, comprises data collected from multiple collaborators. Diagnostic test manufacturers develop sequence-based tests to identify infectious agents and/or to detect resistance or virulence markers; will use this database to advance their development programs and to support the regulatory science review of such tests. This work will facilitate the development of these tests, which are aimed at improving patient outcomes. Continued success of the database and adoption by the community is contingent on populating and curating the database, which in turn will support development of guidance and standards for clinical use of this technology. Discussions held at a relating public workshop on advancing regulatory science for high throughput sequencing devices for microbial identification and detection of antimicrobial resistance markers were essential to establish the safety and effectiveness of these devices.

Aureiomonas sp. AU20 has sole copy of rrn operon not on the chromosome but on a 9.4-kb replicon. To explore the distribution of rrn-lacking chromosome and rrn-plasmid, we sequenced genomes of additional 12 strains belonging to the family Aurantimonadaceae.
record.sequencingCenters: Graduate School of Life Sciences, Tohoku University

record.isolationSource: Water From A Saline Meromictic Lagoon

record.comments: Genome sequence of proteorhodopsin-bearing Flavobacterium isolate from a meromictic lagoon (Burton Lake) located in Eastern Antarctica. Will be used for comparative genomics, functional genomics (proteomics) and physiological studies.

record.isolationComments: Isolated from Cheseapeake Bay bottom sediments was determined to be one of the two strongest methylators of mercury among the Desulfovibrio cell lines examined, methylating 62
record.comments: Desulfovibrio isolate X2 is a d-Proteobacterium of the Desulfovibrionales isolated from Cheseapeake Bay bottom sediments was determined to be one of the two strongest methylators of mercury among the Desulfovibrio cell lines examined, methylating 62.2 ± 13.7% as compared with the model Desulfovibrio desulfuricans ND132 that methylated 53.6 ± 5.6% of the input Hg in an identical assay. We present the genome sequence of Desulfovibrio isolate X2 as a resource for evaluation of genetic elements associated with the ability of bacterial to methylate mercury.

record.fullScientificName: Arenibacter latericius Ivanova et al. 2001 emend. Nedashkovskaya et al. 2006
record.comments: Genomic Encyclopedia of Type Strains, Phase I: one thousand microbial genomes (KMG) project. The goal of the Genomic Encyclopedia of Bacteria and Archaea (GEBA) initiative is to sequence genomes to fill phylogenetic gaps, generating reference genomes for every major and minor group of bacteria and archaea. Currently sequenced genomes have provided highly uneven coverage of the type strain material present in public culture collections. The Microbial Earth Project is an initiative of the Microbial Genomics Program of the DOE Joint Genome Institute that focuses on 1000 Type strains from the DSMZ and ATCC repositories.

Edwardsiella bacteria are leading fish pathogens causing huge losses to aquaculture industries worldwide. However, the taxa are now widely recognized to be misclassified, which hurdled the understanding of the epidemiology and development of effective diagnostics and vaccines. Current-ly the genus Edwardsiella is divided into three species Edwardsiella tarda, E. ictaluri, E. hoshinae. Previous phylogenomic analysis revealed that two genomics types (genotypes), EdwGI and EdwGII, exist in E. tarda, and EdwGI represents a genotype of fish pathogens in the Edwardsiella lineage and is proposed as E. piscicida, sp. nov..
record.sequencingCenters: East China University of Science and Technology

record.isolationComments: Isolated from marine environment
record.comments: The oxygen-resistant NiFe hydrogenase of H. marinus, involved in the H2 metabolism and energy generation, is an important model enzyme for study and development of stable H2 catalyst working under aerobic condition. The biosynthesis of the hydrogenase with its high complexity, as well as the mechanism of the extreme O2 resistance has not been fully understood. We expect the genome scale study will provide plentiful clues and useful information for elucidating the fundamentals of this interesting enzyme and the relevant metabolisms. Also, insight can be obtained regarding the carbon and hydrogen cycle in marine ecosystem, since the organism is the first obligate aerobic H2 oxidizer isolated from marine environment.
record.sequencingCenters: Pohang University of Science and Technology

We hypothesized that rifampicin passage leads to an accumulation of genomic mutations that, by chance, reduce virulence. Consequently, we examined proteomic, LPS and single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) differences for two F. psychrophilum strains (CSF 259-93 and THC 02-90) that were passaged with and without rifampicin selection.

FDA, in collaboration with the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), the Department of Defense (DoD) and the Institute for Genome Sciences at the University of Maryland, established a publicly available, well-curated reference database (FDA-ARGOS: dAtabase for Regulatory Grade micrObial Sequences; BioProject 231221) of regulatory-grade-quality sequences from diverse infectious microorganisms. This database, which is still growing, comprises data collected from multiple collaborators. Diagnostic test manufacturers develop sequence-based tests to identify infectious agents and/or to detect resistance or virulence markers; will use this database to advance their development programs and to support the regulatory science review of such tests. This work will facilitate the development of these tests, which are aimed at improving patient outcomes. Continued success of the database and adoption by the community is contingent on populating and curating the database, which in turn will support development of guidance and standards for clinical use of this technology. Discussions held at a relating public workshop on advancing regulatory science for high throughput sequencing devices for microbial identification and detection of antimicrobial resistance markers were essential to establish the safety and effectiveness of these devices.

The recently elucidated complete genome sequence of Vibrio harveyi CAIM 1792 provides an opportunity to understand the genetic determinants responsible for the unique morbidity and mortality this organism causes when pathogenizing the white shrimp, Litopenaeus vannamei. In this study, we compared the genome of V. harveyi CAIM 1792 with draft genome sequences from other V. harveyi strains and closely related species (V. owensii, V. rotiferianus, V. campbellii) to determine the level of genetic conservation among these strains/species and to identify genetic determinants involved in pathogenicity which are unique to V. harveyi CAIM 1792.

Sequencing genomes of the Vibrio owensii type strain (DY05T), which is pathogenic to lobster larvae, and Vibrio owensii strain 47666-1, which is pathogenic to prawns. The genome sequences will be used for phylogeny and comparative genomics studies with focus on species in the Harveyi clade.

Currently sequenced genomes have provided highly uneven coverage of the type strain material present in public culture collections. The Microbial Earth Project is an initiative of the Microbial Genomics Program of the DOE Joint Genome Institute that focuses on 1000 Type strains from the DSMZ and ATCC repositories.

The aim of this project is to collect comparative genome sequence data across multiple strains of the important human pathogens Streptococcus agalactiae for the purpose of analyzing selection pressure and demographic history, employing population genetic based methods.

record.comments: Labrenzia aggregata is a member of the family Rhodobacteraceae reclassified in 2007 by Biebl et al. as a comb. nov. of Stappia aggregata (Uchino et al. 1998) sp. nov., nom.rev. of an isolate assigned to Agrobacterium genus by Ahrens et al in 1968. Genome sequencing of Labrenzia aggregata CECT 4801 was done using the Illumina Miseq system by the Central Service of Support to Experimental Research (SCSIE) of the University of Valencia (Spain).

record.comments: Biotype I Vibrio vulnificus, which causes severe invasive infections from consumption of oysters, is split into two genotypes with all sequenced clinical isolates from the C genotypes. We report here whole genome sequencing of two clinical isolates and two closely linked oyster isolates from the E genotype for comparative studies.

Biotype I Vibrio vulnificus, which causes severe invasive infections from consumption of oysters, is split into two genotypes with all sequenced clinical isolates from the C genotypes. We report here whole genome sequencing of two clinical isolates and two closely linked oyster isolates from the E genotype for comparative studies.

record.isolationComments: Isolated from samples obtained in June, 1998, on the research vessel Atlantis by using the deep-ocean-submersible vessel ALVIN at the hydrothermal vents located in the Main Endeavor Segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the Pacific Ocean (47
record.comments: This strain was isolated from samples obtained in June, 1998, on the research vessel Atlantis by using the deep-ocean-submersible vessel ALVIN at the hydrothermal vents located in the Main Endeavor Segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the Pacific Ocean (47.57’N, 129.05’W), from depths of 2,000 to 2,200 m.The colonies were transparent and creamy, and was tellurite-reducing strain to grow media containing K2TeO3 and accumulate metallic tellurium. The genomic analysis would be helpful for the research on its metalloid resistance.
record.sequencingCenters: Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences

record.isolationComments: Isolated from samples obtained in June, 1998, on the research vessel Atlantis by using the deep-ocean-submersible vessel ALVIN at the hydrothermal vents located in the Main Endeavor Segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the Pacific Ocean (47
record.comments: This strain was isolated from samples obtained in June, 1998, on the research vessel Atlantis by using the deep-ocean-submersible vessel ALVIN at the hydrothermal vents located in the Main Endeavor Segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the Pacific Ocean (47.57’N, 129.05’W), from depths of 2,000 to 2,200 m.The colonies were transparent and creamy, and was selenite-reducing strain to grow media containing Na2SeO3 and accumulate metallic selenium. The genomic analysis would be helpful for the research on its metalloid resistance.
record.sequencingCenters: Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences

record.comments: Genomic Encyclopedia of Type Strains, Phase I: one thousand microbial genomes (KMG) project. The goal of the Genomic Encyclopedia of Bacteria and Archaea (GEBA) initiative is to sequence genomes to fill phylogenetic gaps, generating reference genomes for every major and minor group of bacteria and archaea. Currently sequenced genomes have provided highly uneven coverage of the type strain material present in public culture collections. The Microbial Earth Project is an initiative of the Microbial Genomics Program of the DOE Joint Genome Institute that focuses on 1000 Type strains from the DSMZ and ATCC repositories.
Currently encompasses whole genome sequencing of cultured Vibrio parahaemolyticus as part of a surveillance project for the rapid detection foodborne illness outbreaks.
Genome was sequenced as part of the study which compares eight Planktothrix genomes.

The recently elucidated complete genome sequence of Vibrio harveyi CAIM 1792 provides an opportunity to understand the genetic determinants responsible for the unique morbidity and mortality this organism causes when pathogenizing the white shrimp, Litopenaeus vannamei. In this study, we compared the genome of V. harveyi CAIM 1792 with draft genome sequences from other V. harveyi strains and closely related species (V. owensii, V. rotiferianus, V. campbellii) to determine the level of genetic conservation among these strains/species and to identify genetic determinants involved in pathogenicity which are unique to V. harveyi CAIM 1792.

The recently elucidated complete genome sequence of Vibrio harveyi CAIM 1792 provides an opportunity to understand the genetic determinants responsible for the unique morbidity and mortality this organism causes when pathogenizing the white shrimp, Litopenaeus vannamei. In this study, we compared the genome of V. harveyi CAIM 1792 with draft genome sequences from other V. harveyi strains and closely related species (V. owensii, V. rotiferianus, V. campbellii) to determine the level of genetic conservation among these strains/species and to identify genetic determinants involved in pathogenicity which are unique to V. harveyi CAIM 1792.

record.isolationComments: Isolated from seawater in the Chukchi Sea
record.comments: The psychrotolerant Pseudoalteromonas sp. BSw20308 was isolated from seawater in the Chukchi Sea. It can produce various extracellular enzymes, which can degrade polysaccharides and proteins. Here, we present the draft genome sequence of BSw20308 to provide further information for the ecological function and adaptation of the genus Pseudoalteromonas in Arctic marine environment.

record.comments: The cold-adapted Psychromonas sp. strain SP041 was isolated from sandy beach sediment collected on the coast of Svalbard Norway as part of an ongoing bioprospecting project that aims to identify novel bacteria with biotechnological potential. Here we present the 4.8-Mb draft genome sequence, together with details regarding the origin of the strain and its sequence assembly.

record.isolationComments: Isolated from plum island (MA,USA) on vibrio selective media
record.comments: Isolated from plum island (MA,USA) on vibrio selective media.

Sea ice diatoms living in the same habitat as this bacterium have genes for ice-binding proteins. These genes may have been acquired from bacteria. F. frigoris has a gene for an ice-binding protein that is 44% identical (at a.a. sequence level) to a diatom gene, and demonstrates that an opportunity for horizontal gene transfer from bacteria to diatoms exists.

record.fullScientificName: Streptococcus phocae subsp. salmonis Avendaño-Herrera et al. 2014
record.isolationComments: Isolated from Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar)
record.comments: Streptococcus phocae is a Gram-positive fish pathogen that has an important impact on the Chilean salmon industry. Here, we report the genome sequence of S. phocae strain C-4 isolated from Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar). The genome sequence of S. phocae revealed a number of interesting features and genes related to its possible virulence factors, including genes assocciated to colonization, biofilm formation, invasion, and destruction of the host tissues such as hemolysins, collagen adhesion protein and capsule biosynthesis proteins.
